intro: Calcitrapa lanceolata, commonly known as the lanceleaf catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the northeastern United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae, which includes many showy, herbaceous plants. The plant is characterized by its linear, lance-shaped leaves and clusters of small, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, sandy soils and is often found in open woods or along stream banks. Calcitrapa lanceolata is also known for its hairy stems and its ability to attract pollinators such as bees and flies.
